description:
Sebastes umbrosus, commonly known as the dusky rockfish, is a species of marine fish belonging to the genus Sebastes, which is part of the family Sebastidae. The dusky rockfish is found in the northeastern Pacific Ocean, inhabiting coastal waters from Alaska to Baja California.

The dusky rockfish is a medium-sized fish, typically reaching lengths of around 40 centimeters (16 inches). It has a robust, compact body shape with a large, rounded head. The coloration of the dusky rockfish is generally dark brown or grayish-brown, with small darker spots or blotches scattered across its body and fins.

This species is known to inhabit rocky, reef-like environments, often in association with kelp forests or other complex underwater structures. Dusky rockfish are considered to be relatively sedentary, spending much of their time in a particular area or territory. They are predatory fish, feeding on a variety of small invertebrates and other fish species.

Sebastes umbrosus is an important component of the Pacific Coast's marine ecosystem, serving as both a predator and prey within the food web. It is also of commercial and recreational importance, being targeted by fisheries in various regions of its distribution.
